title: Find Electric Field between 2 Charged Plates

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A group of students are to experimentally determine the magnitude of the electric field <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between two parallel conducting plates connected to a variable power supply as shown in the diagram. The students are unable to read the display on the power supply and do not have access to metersticks or rulers. A nonconducting ball of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hangs on an insulated string between the plates and comes to equilibrium while hanging at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the vertical, as shown. The students can charge the ball to varying amounts and measure the charge of the ball <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with an electrometer. The students are expected to determine the magnitude of the electric field by plotting their data in a graph. (a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

A group of students are to experimentally determine the magnitude of the electric field <math alttext="E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between two parallel conducting plates connected to a variable power supply as shown in the diagram. The students are unable to read the display on the power supply and do not have access to metersticks or rulers. A nonconducting ball of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hangs on an insulated string between the plates and comes to equilibrium while hanging at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the vertical, as shown. The students can charge the ball to varying amounts and measure the charge of the ball <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with an electrometer. The students are expected to determine the magnitude of the electric field by plotting their data in a graph. (a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine the magnitude of the electric field between the two plates. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the magnitude of the electric field?
(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the magnitude of the electric field.

(e) Two groups with similar laboratory setups are comparing their results. Group 1 suspended the ball from a longer string such that the ball reached equilibrium near the center of the plates. Group 2 suspended the ball from a short string such that the ball reached equilibrium near the top of the plates. Is Group 1’s data more likely, less likely, or equally likely to produce an accurate determination of the magnitude of the electric field between the plates? Justify your answer.
